France and England declared war on Germany on September 3, 1939, two days after Germany invaded Poland. Technically, Germany was already at war with France when the German army attacked in May 1940. They invaded Holland and Belgium to keep the French and British from attacking Germany from there.

The German invasion of Belgium began on August 4, 1914. Earlier, on July 24, the Belgian government had announced that if war came it would uphold its neutrality. The Belgian government mobilised its armed forces on July 31 and a state of Kriegsgefahr (danger of war) was proclaimed in Germany. On August 1 the German government sent an ultimatum to Belgium, demanding passage through the country and German forces invaded Luxembourg.

Neutral Belgium rejected this idea, so the Germans decided to invade through Belgium instead. France also wanted to move their troops into Belgium, but Belgium originally rejected this suggestion as well, in the hope of avoiding any war on Belgian soil. The Germans in fact made such a request.

Best Answer: In World War I Belgium was neutral and they rejected Germany's demand to use Belgium as an invasion route into France. Britain had treaty ties guaranteeing the neutrality of Belgium. So then Britain warned Germany to call off the planned invasion by midnight of August 4, 1914 or the two countries would be at war. Germany's ruler, Kaiser Wilhelm, pretty much just laughed at Britain and they invaded Belgium anyway.
